• The Declaration does not grant any State, group, or individual the right to engage in activities that aim to destroy any of the rights and freedoms mentioned in the Declaration.

 	• No State, group, or individual can undertake any activities or perform any acts that aim to limit or curtail the rights and freedoms mentioned in the Declaration.

 	• The rights and freedoms mentioned in the Declaration are universal, meaning that they apply to everyone.

 	• The rights and freedoms mentioned in the Declaration are inalienable, which means that they cannot be taken away or surrendered by any person or authority.

 	• The rights and freedoms mentioned in the Declaration are indivisible, meaning that they are interdependent and interrelated and that the violation of one right can have a cascading effect on the enjoyment of other rights.
